titleStmt.title: The iust reckenyng or accompt of the whole nomber of the yeares, from the beginnyng of the world vnto this present yere of. 1547 A certaine and sure declaracion that the world is at an ende. Of the last day of iudgement, or day of dome, and howe it shal come to passe. Translated out of the Germaine tonge into Englishe by Anthony Scoloker the .6. daye of July. Anno D[omi]ni. 1547.

titleStmt.title: The iust reckenyng or accompt of the whole nomber of the yeares, from the beginnyng of the world vnto this present yere of. 1547 A certaine and sure declaracion that the world is at an ende. Of the last day of iudgement, or day of dome, and howe it shal come to passe. Translated out of the Germaine tonge into Englishe by Anthony Scoloker the .6. daye of July. Anno D[omi]ni. 1547.
titleStmt.author: Scoloker, Anthony, fl. 1548.

notesStmt.note: Printing sometimes attributed to Anthony Skoloker; cf. Freeman, Janet Ing, "Anthony Skoloker, the 'Just Reckoning printer' and the earliest Ipswich printing", Transactions of the Cambridge Bibliographical Society, v.IX, part 5.
Imperfect; lacks all after leaf A7.
Reproduction of the original in the Cambridge University Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

2010-04 Mona LogarboText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: The iuſt reckenyng or accompt of the whole nomber of the yeares, from the beginnyng of the world vnto this preſente yere of .1547.
A certaine and ſure declaracion that the world is at an ende.
Of the laſt day of iudgement, or day of dome, and howe it ſhal come to paſſe.
Tranſlated out of the Germaine tonge into Engliſhe by Anthony Scoloker the .6. daye of Iuly. Anno Dn̄i. 1547.

q.p: Watche therfore for ye knewe neither the daye nor yet the howre when the ſonne of man ☞ ſhall come. ☜

figure.figDesc: inverted triangle composed of decorative elements

div.head: ¶To the Reader.
div.p: FOraſmuch as many writers haue diuerſly wrytten of the accompt of the time. Here haſte thou (gentle reader) the iuſte nomber of the yeares from the beginnyng of the world vnto this preſēt yere of .1547. diligētly gathered out of the Bible.

Here haſt thou alſo a certaine and ſure declaracion that the daie of dome is at hād: not tha • we wil or can declare the very houre,Act. 1. as Chriſt ſayth. Actes. 1. But to the intēt that we ſhuld be ready at all times as true faithful ſeruātes which waite for the cōmyng of their Lord for he ſhall not tary but com • very ſhortly.Luke. 12. Therfore let vs watche and pray for we know neither houre nor time.

list.head: The nōber of the yeares brefely comprehended.
list.item: The .1. accompt. FRom the begynnynge of the world vnto the floud, are .1656. yeares.
The .2. accompt. Frō the floud vnto the tyme that Abraham departed out of Chaldea, are .363. yeares, and 10. daies.
The .3. Accompt. From Abrahams departing out of Chaldea til the Childrē of Iſrael wēt out of Egipt, are 400. and .30. yeares.
The .4. Accompt. From the departyng of the childrē of Iſrael out of Egipt, till the firſt buildyng of the tē ple, or tyll the .4. yere of the reigne of Salomon, are .4700. yeares.
The 5. accompt. From the firſt buyldynge of the Temple tyl the captyuitie of Babylon, are 419. yeres and 6. monethes.
The 6. accompt. From the captyuitie af Babylon, tyl that Ieruſalem was buylte agayne, are 143. yeres.
The 7. accompt. From the tyme that Ieruſalem was buylt agayne, tyl the Byrthe of our ſauiour Chriſt, are 483. yeres.

div.p: From the byrth of Chriſt vnto this preſent yere are, 1547. Thus doth the wholl ſumme of the yeres frō the begynnynge of the world, vnto this preſent yere of 47. amount to 5521. and ſomwhat more than halfe a yere.

The declaracion of the before named nomber,The firſt accompt. ſet forth at large, from the begynnynge of the world, to ye tyme of ye floud, are 1656. yeres, which are nombred after this maner foloīge.Geneſ. 5.

list.item: Adam, beyng of the age of 130. begatte Seth.
Seth, beyng old 105,Geneſ. 5. yeres begatte Enos.
Enos, beinge olde 90.Geneſ. 5. yere begatte Cainan.Geneſ. 5.
Cainan, being olde 60 yere, begatte Malalehel.
Malalehel, beīg olde 65.Geneſ. 5. yeres begatte Iared.
Iared, beyng olde 162.Geneſ. 5. begatte Enoch.
Enoch, beyng olde 65,Geneſ. 5. yere begatte Mathuſalem.
Mathuſalem, beynge olde 97,Geneſis. 5. yere begatte Lamech.
Lamech, beyng olde 182,Geneſ. 5. yere begatte Noe.

Noe was of ye age of 600,Geneſ. 7. yeres
whan the floud was vpon the earthe.

div.p: This moūteth al in one ſūme 1656 yeares.
From the floud till the tyme that Abrahā went out of Chaldea, are .363. yeares and .10. daies whiche are nombred thus.

list.item: Geneſis. 8.The floud continued a yere and, 10. daies.
Geneſ. 11.Sem the ſonne of Noe begatt Arphaxat 2. yere after ye floud.
Geneſ. 11.Arphaxat beyng olde .35. yere begatte Sale.
Geneſ. 11.Sale, beyng old .30. yere begat Heber.
Geneſ. 11.Heber, beyng olde .34. yere begatte Phalech.
Geneſ. 11.Phalech, beynge olde .30. yere begatte Reu.
Geneſ. 11.Reu, beyng olde .37. yere begat Saruch.

Geneſ. 11.Saruch, being old .30. yere begatte
Nachor.
Nachor, beyng olde 29. yere begatte Thare.Geneſ. 11.
Thare, beyng olde .70. yere,Geneſ. 11. begatte Abraham.
Abraham, beyng olde .70.Geneſ. 11. yere departed out of Vr.

div.p: From Abrahās departing out of Chaldea tyll that the chyldren of Iſraell went out of Egipte, are .430.The third accompt. yere whiche are nombred thus.

list.item: Abrahā was fiue yere at Charam in the .705.Geneſis. 12. yere departed he from thens.
In the .25.Gene. 1 • . yere of his departynge from thens (which was in the .100. yere of gis age) he begatte Iſaac.
Iſaac being olde .3.Gene. 27. ſcore yere begatte Iacob.
Gene. 47.Iacob was old 130, yere when he wt al his family & houſhold went into Egypt.
Act. 7.Hereof muſt be rebated 80, yeres, for ſo olde was Moyſes when he led the chyldrē of Iſraell out of Egypt.

The ouer plus or reſt of the yeres, to ſay 130, yeres muſt be deuyded of Moyſes father & graūdfather, namely Amram and Chath, ſo that Chath beynge olde 67, yeres begatte Amram Moyſes father: And Amram beyng 65, yeres of age begatte Moyſes, who led the childrē of Iſrael out of Egypt in the 80, yere of his age.

div.p: Exod. 12. Galat. 3.This amounteth together to 430, as it appereth Exod 12, and Galath. 3.

From the goynge fourth out of Egypt tyl ye firſt byldīg of ye The. 4. accompt.
Temple, or tyll the, 4, yere of the Reygne of Salomon are 480, yere whiche muſt be counted thus,Deut. 1.

list.item: Moſes reigned in the deſert, 40, yere,
Ioſue and Othoniel, 40, yere,Iudic. 3.
Aioth, 80, yere,Iudic. 8.
Delbora .40. yere.Iudic. 8.
Gedeon .40. yere.Iudic. 9. Iudic. 10.
Abimelech .3. yere.
Thola .22. yere.Iudic. 10. Iudic. 10.
After that were they .28. yere without head, til ye time of Iepthae.
Iepthae reigned .6. yere.Iudic. 12. Iudic. 12. Iudic, 12. Iudi. 12
Abeſſam .7, yere,
Elon, 10, yere,
Abdon, 8, yere,
Sampſon, 20, yere,Iudi. 16. 1. Samuel, 4
Heli was bothe Iudge & preſt 40. yere.
Samuel and Saul haue reigned, 40, yere,Act. 3
2. Regum. 5.Dauid was 40. yere kynge.
3. Reg. 6.Salomon beganne to buylde the Temple in the fourth yere of his reygne.

div.p: This amounteth to gether to 470. yere, whiche are alſo ſo nombred 3. Regum. 6.
The fifth accompt.From the firſt buyldyng of the Temple, tyl the captyuytie of Babilon, are 419. yeres and 6. monethes which muſt be rekened thus.

list.item: 5. Regum. 11.Salomō reigned yet 63. yeres.
1. Paril. 12.Roboam 17. yere.
2. Paral. 13.Abia 3. yere.
3. Reg. 15. 3. Reg. 22.Aſa 41. yere
Ioſaphat 25. yere.
2. Para. 21.Ioram 8. yere.
4. Reg. 8.Ochoſias 1. yere
4. Reg. 11. 4. Reg. 12.Athalia was 7. yere Quene.
Ioas' 40 yere.
4. Regū. 14.Amaſias 29. yere
Oſias 52. yere,4. Reg. 15.
Ioatham 16. yere.4. Reg. 15.
Achas 16. yere.4 Reg. 16. 4. Reg. 18.
Ezechias 29. yere
Manaſſes 55. yere.4. Reg. 21.
Amon 2. yere.4. Reg. 21. 4. Reg. 22.
Ioſyas 31. yere.
Ioachas 3. monethes.4. Reg. 23.
Ioakim Eliachim 9. yere.4. Reg. 23. 4. Reg. 34.
Ioachī Iochonias 3. monethes

In whoſe tyme beganne the Captyuitye of Babylon in the 11. yere of zedechia whā the temple and cytye was burned as apereth in the 1.Matt. 1. chap. of Mat. and alſo in the 24, and 25.Iere. 24.25. chap. ter of Hieremy the prophet.

div.p: Which amounteth al in one ſōe 419. yeres and 6. monethes.
From the captiuitye of Babylon til the buyldyng againe of Ieruſalem, are 143. yere.The ſixte accompt.

list.item: Iere. 24.25.The Captiuitie continued .60, yere.1, Eſdra, 1,
In the firſt yere of the reigne of king Cyrus were the captiues or priſōers deliuerd,
In the ſecōd yere of Cirus,1, Eſdra, 2, mē beganne to build the Temple.
In the .46.1, Eſdra, 6, yere was the tēple cōplete & finiſhed that is in the 6, yere of the reigne of king Darius.Nehemias, 2
In the, 20, yere of his reigne, was Nehemias releaſed, and came for to build the citie.

div.p: In the .22.Nehem, 5, yere of Darius was the citie finiſhed, ſo that the nō ber of yeres of the buildyng again of the Tēple are, 26, which amoūteth togither to 143. yere.
The, 7, accompt.From the buildyng againe of Ieruſalem til the comming of Chriſt are .483, yere, which are nombred thus.

list.item:
It is written in the, 9, Chap
of Daniell, of the goyng for the or procedyng of the word (that is to ſaye) from the tyme that Ieruſalem ſhall be buylte agayne tyll the time of the true Meſſias and Sauiour Chriſt are .67. wekes,Note this wel, Lu, 25 and one weke is counted here for .7. yere as it appeareth, Leuiticus. 25.
Thus make, 67, wekes. 483, yere, and ſo manye yeares is it frō the reigne of Darius, til ye 42, yere of the reigne of Auguſtus, in which yere Chriſt was borne.

Thus the noumber of the yeres from the beginnynge of the worlde tyll the byrthe of Chriſte are .3, thouſande, 974, & lyttell more than halfe a yere, and from the byrthe of Chriſt tyll this preſent yere of, 47, is clere and manyfeſt inough.
So that from the begynnyng of the worlde vnto this preſēt yere, are 5521. yere & ſomewhat more then halfe a yere.

div.p: Of the ende of the world, and of the daye of dome or Iudgement.
I wyll not here go about to ſerche out the very hour of the Iudgement (for God 〈◊〉 in his powre, hath hydden the ſame) but manyfeſtly declare that the day is euen at hand.

ELyas hath ſpoken tha • the worlde ſhulde ſtand aboute 6000. yere, whic • nombre is deuyded after thi • maner 2000 yere voyde wit •
out anye lawe.
